title: Scroll Navigation - Comprehensive Usage Examples
description: Complete example configurations for one-page navigation with scroll indicators, tooltips, progress tracking, and custom positioning

examples.name: Dot Navigation Right Side (Classic Portfolio)
examples.description: Traditional right-side dot navigation with icons and tooltips
examples.visualDescription: Vertical dots on right edge, FontAwesome icons, tooltips on left hover, active state highlights current section
examples.useCase: Creative portfolios, personal websites, one-page resumes, freelancer sites, agency showcases
notes: style-1 = dot indicators with icons (most common for portfolios)
scrollPosition: 'right' = fixed right edge positioning
Responsive scrollOffset: 50px desktop, 30px tablet, 20px mobile
sectionId must match HTML element ID (e.g., <div id='hero'>)
activeOffset: 100 = section becomes active 100px before top of viewport
tooltipPosition: 'left' = tooltips appear on left side of dots (right-side nav)
FontAwesome icons require Font Awesome library loaded on site

examples.name: Text Label Navigation Left (Corporate Site)
examples.description: Left-side text label navigation with full section names
examples.visualDescription: Vertical text labels on left edge, no icons, tooltips on right, clean corporate aesthetic
examples.useCase: Corporate websites, business landing pages, service providers, consulting firms, B2B sites
notes: style-2 = text labels visible (better for longer section names)
scrollPosition: 'left' = fixed left edge positioning
6 sections = good for comprehensive business sites
No icons in style-2, only text labels shown
Tooltips provide additional context beyond label text
scrollSpeed: 1200ms = slightly slower for professional feel
Longer section names readable without hover (unlike dots)

examples.name: Horizontal Top Navigation (Presentation Mode)
examples.description: Horizontal dot navigation at top for slide-style layouts
examples.visualDescription: Horizontal dots centered at top edge, 80px offset, bottom tooltips, minimal distraction
examples.useCase: Presentation-style landing pages, pitch decks, product launches, webinar pages, slide-based storytelling
notes: scrollDirection: 'horizontal' = dots arranged horizontally
scrollPosition: 'top' = fixed top edge (works with horizontal direction)
80px offset accounts for fixed header navigation
tooltipPosition: 'bottom' = tooltips below dots (top nav)
Faster scrollSpeed: 800ms for quick slide transitions
activeOffset: 50 = tighter activation for slide-style sections
Works well with full-viewport height sections (100vh)

examples.name: Progress Bar Navigation (Reading Progress)
examples.description: Dot navigation with scroll progress bar indicator
examples.visualDescription: Right-side dots with top progress bar showing page scroll percentage, visual feedback for long content
examples.useCase: Long-form articles, documentation, tutorials, ebooks, research papers, educational content, multi-chapter guides
notes: progressBar: true = adds horizontal progress indicator
progressPosition: 'top' = progress bar at top of page
Progress bar fills as user scrolls down page
Provides visual feedback on reading progress
activeOffset: 120 = accounts for longer content sections
Great for content >3000 words where users need orientation
Progress bar uses theme accent color for fill

examples.name: Minimal Dot Navigation (Clean Design)
examples.description: Ultra-minimal dot navigation without icons or tooltips
examples.visualDescription: Clean dots on right, no icons, no tooltips, minimal visual distraction, modern aesthetic
examples.useCase: Minimalist designs, modern SaaS sites, clean portfolios, product pages, mobile-first sites
notes: showTooltip: false = no hover tooltips for cleaner look
No icons specified in repeater items (dots only)
4 sections = good for short landing pages
Minimal visual distraction from content
Works well with bold, full-width section designs
Lower cognitive load for users (simple dots only)
Responsive offset: smaller on mobile to maximize screen space

examples.name: Icon-Rich Navigation (Visual Storytelling)
examples.description: Colorful icon-based navigation with descriptive tooltips
examples.visualDescription: Large icons in dots, vibrant visual indicators, detailed tooltips, engaging interaction
examples.useCase: Brand storytelling, nonprofit sites, mission-driven companies, about pages, annual reports, impact pages
notes: 7 sections = good for comprehensive storytelling
Detailed tooltips provide additional context
Icons visually reinforce section themes
sectionId uses descriptive naming (our-vision, our-mission)
Works well with image-heavy, narrative-driven content
scrollSpeed: 1100ms = moderate pace for reading flow
Icon colors can be customized via CSS to match brand

examples.name: Mobile-Responsive Navigation (Desktop Only)
examples.description: Desktop-focused navigation hidden on mobile devices
examples.visualDescription: Full navigation on desktop/tablet, hidden on mobile (< 768px), prevents small-screen clutter
examples.useCase: Sites with complex mobile navigation, hamburger menu sites, mobile-first designs where fixed nav conflicts
notes: hideOnMobile: true = navigation hidden on screens < 768px width
Prevents scroll nav from conflicting with mobile hamburger menus
Mobile users rely on traditional scroll or mobile nav menu
scrollOffset only defined for md/sm (not xs)
Desktop users get enhanced navigation experience
Consider accessibility - mobile users lose quick jump navigation
Combine with tp-mobile-menu for comprehensive navigation strategy

examples.name: Fast Navigation (Long Page Quick Jump)
examples.description: Super-fast scrolling for very long pages with many sections
examples.visualDescription: Quick 600ms scroll animation, tight active detection, 8 sections, efficient navigation for content-heavy pages
examples.useCase: Academic papers, research reports, documentation, long-form journalism, technical guides, multi-section tutorials
notes: scrollSpeed: 600ms = fastest recommended (< 500ms feels jarring)
style-2 text labels = better for academic/formal content
8 sections = typical research paper structure
activeOffset: 60 = tight detection for dense content
progressBar at bottom = less intrusive for reading
Fast scrolling reduces wait time between sections
Left-side positioning = doesn't interfere with right-side footnotes/margins
Text labels more descriptive than dots for complex topics

with_progress_bar.description: Add scroll progress indicator for long content

scrollNavStyle.description: style-1 = dot indicators with icons, style-2 = text labels (no icons)

itemSchema.title: Section title/label
itemSchema.sectionId: HTML element ID (without #) - MUST exist on page
itemSchema.icon: Font Awesome class (style-1 only, e.g., 'fas fa-home')

scrollDirection.description: vertical = left/right positioning, horizontal = top/bottom positioning

scrollPosition.description: Page position - vertical: left/right, horizontal: top/bottom

scrollSpeed.description: Scroll animation duration - too fast (<500ms) feels jarring, too slow (>2000ms) frustrates

activeOffset.description: Offset for active section detection - section becomes active this many pixels before viewport top

showTooltip.description: Show hover tooltips on navigation items

tooltipPosition.description: Tooltip placement relative to nav item

progressPosition.description: Progress bar position (only if progressBar: true)

warnings: sectionId MUST match actual HTML element IDs on page - navigation won't work if IDs don't exist
Only ONE tp-scroll-navigation block per page - multiple instances will conflict
Requires page sections to have unique IDs (e.g., <div id='about'>)
FontAwesome icons require Font Awesome library loaded - icons won't show without it
style-2 (text labels) ignores icon attribute - don't waste time setting icons for style-2
progressBar requires sufficient page height (>2000px) to be meaningful
hideOnMobile: true removes navigation for mobile users - ensure alternative navigation exists
Maximum 10 navigation items recommended - more creates visual clutter
commonMistakes: Missing HTML element IDs on page - navigation clicks do nothing
Setting icons in style-2 - style-2 only shows text labels, icons are ignored
Wrong tooltip position - tooltipPosition: 'right' for scrollPosition: 'right' (tooltips hidden off-screen)
Too many items - 12+ navigation items creates overwhelming visual clutter
scrollSpeed too slow (>2000ms) - users get impatient waiting for scroll animation
Not loading Font Awesome - icons don't show if library missing
Forgetting responsive scrollOffset - fixed position on mobile may overlap content
Using horizontal direction with left/right position - creates broken layout
bestPractices: Use 4-6 navigation items for optimal balance (not too few, not too many)
Match sectionId exactly to HTML element IDs (case-sensitive)
Choose tooltip position opposite of scroll position (right nav = left tooltips)
Test on actual devices - fixed positioning can conflict with mobile UI
Provide descriptive tooltips that add value beyond the label
Use style-1 (dots) for minimal designs, style-2 (text) for corporate/formal sites
Set scrollSpeed: 800-1200ms for balanced feel (1000ms is sweet spot)
Use progressBar: true only for long content (>3000 words / >5 sections)
Ensure section IDs are semantic (use 'our-services' not 'section-2')
Add hideOnMobile: true if navigation conflicts with mobile hamburger menu
Test active state detection - adjust activeOffset if sections activate too early/late
Use consistent icon style (all solid, or all outline) for visual harmony
Combine with tp-smooth-scroll for enhanced scrolling experience
Ensure sufficient scrollOffset to avoid overlapping with fixed headers
Make navigation visually subtle - shouldn't dominate the design
accessibilityNotes: Keyboard navigation: Tab to focus navigation items, Enter/Space to activate
Screen readers announce each navigation item with tooltip text
Active state should have sufficient color contrast (WCAG AA: 4.5:1)
Tooltips should be brief and descriptive for screen reader users
Provide alternative skip-to-section links in header for keyboard-only users
Focus indicators must be visible on navigation dots/labels
ARIA labels automatically added to navigation items
progressBar has aria-valuenow for screen readers (announces scroll percentage)
Ensure navigation doesn't trap keyboard focus - users can Tab away
Test with keyboard only - all sections must be accessible without mouse
Consider users with motion sensitivity - smooth scroll animations may cause discomfort
Provide option to disable smooth scrolling via prefers-reduced-motion CSS
performanceConsiderations: Scroll navigation uses Intersection Observer API - minimal performance impact
Active section detection uses IntersectionObserver, not scroll event (efficient)
Smooth scroll animation uses requestAnimationFrame for 60fps
progressBar updates on scroll throttled to 100ms - prevents excessive repaints
Navigation renders once - no re-renders during scroll (optimized React)
Icon fonts (Font Awesome) ~80KB - consider SVG icons for smaller footprint
Works smoothly with 10+ sections without performance degradation
Mobile devices may ignore smooth scroll for native momentum scrolling

naming_tips: Use lowercase with hyphens (not underscores or spaces)
Be descriptive but concise (about-us, not section-about-our-company-history)

style-1.visual: Small circular dots, icons inside, active state highlighted
style-1.bestFor: Portfolios, modern designs, creative sites, minimal aesthetics
style-1.tooltip: Essential - dots alone don't convey section names

style-2.visual: Text labels always visible, active state highlighted
style-2.bestFor: Corporate sites, formal designs, longer section names, accessibility-focused
style-2.tooltip: Optional - label already visible, tooltip adds extra context

portfolios.tip: Use style-1 dots on right with icons, 4-5 sections max

corporate_sites.tip: Use style-2 text on left with detailed tooltips, 5-6 sections

presentations.tip: Use horizontal navigation at top for slide-style sections

long_form_content.tip: Add progress bar and fast scrolling for articles/docs

mobile_first.tip: Hide on mobile if conflicts with hamburger menu
